description.narrative: By 2025, prevention of wasting and treatment of children with acute malnutrition services are strengthened to deliver equitable quality and accessible services including during emergencies,which contributes to Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition (Covid), Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2025, chronic malnutrition (stunting) and wasting in children is reduced including in humanitarian situations

mailing-address.narrative: UNICEF House (Kazanchis - Opposite UNECA/German House) P.O. Box 1169 Addis Ababa

sector.narrative: Capacity building for nutrition preparedness and response
Data, research, evaluation, evidence generation, synthesis, and use for SAM and nutrition in emergencies
Maternal nutrition, including information, supplementation and counselling
Technical assistance - Treatment of severe acute malnutrition

title.narrative: UNICEF Programmes in Ethiopia (Social Policy and Evidence for Social Inclusion)
UNICEF Contract Awards through the UN Global Marketplace
2019 Ethiopia: Formative evaluation of UNICEF Ethiopia Country Program Evaluation Report
Ethiopia 2018 Annual Report on Results for Children
Ethiopia 2019 Annual Report on Results for Children
Ethiopia 2020 Annual Report on Results for Children
UNICEF Tender Notices through the UN Global Marketplace

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2025, prevention of wasting and treatment of children with acute malnutrition services are strengthened to deliver equitable quality and accessible services including during emergencies
Number of children aged 6-59 months with SAM who are admitted for treatment
Number of school age children receiving nutrition services through schools with UNICEF support in the reporting year [COVID]
Percentage of health facilities with zero stock out of supplies for the management of SAM in the past 3 months as per national standards (as a proxy for SAM treatment supplies) [COVID]
Existence of a pre-service training curriculum for community-based/integrated management of SAM for health and nutrition workers
Existence of an emergency preparedness plan for nutrition
